block.p: International 3-19 IN CANADA, HEALTH COSTS ARE UP
International 3-19 IN CANADA, HEALTH COSTS ARE UP
Spending for medical care in Canada in recent years has grown nearly as fast as in the United States, and is outstripping the ability of the public sector to pay for it. 1 DUTCH RETURNING LAND TO SEA
A large expanse of farmland that was reclaimed a century ago in the Netherlands is to be flooded again to revert to marshland and lakes. 1 ISRAEL ATTACKS LEBANESE BASE

On Lebanon's coast, Israeli helicopters attacked a marine base belonging to a hard-line Palestinian group, wounding four, officials said. 3 Israel is preparing to use the much-disputed U.S. loan guarantees. 3 ITALY'S 'POLITICAL SOLUTION'
Confronted by an extensive bribery scandal, the Italian Cabinet approved a package of measures presented as a "political solution." 8 ARGENTINA ENDS ATOM PROJECT
Argentina has handed over most of the components of a secretive ballistic missile project known as the Condor II to the United States for destruction, officials said. 9 A BRIDGE ON THE DRINA

In Gorazde, a quiet noontime hour on the bridge is a measure of the hope that the town's defense holds to Muslims of eastern Bosnia. 10 The U.N. failed to win agreement for the evacuation of enclaves. 10 Bosnian peace talks recess for leaders to return home. 10 Weapons that flowed from Thailand to Cambodia are returning. 16 The U.N. operation in Cambodia transforms an isolated town. 16 The arrest of a Japanese politician shakes governing party. 17 A Haitian dissident loses a plea for a U.S. refugee visa. 19 National 20-36 MORE BASE CLOSINGS AT HAND

The Pentagon is proposing a new round of cuts that would close at least 30 major military installations around the country. 1 Clinton said his critics lacked "vision" to bolster the economy. 22 The wealthy seem amenable to a tax rise -- if it cuts the deficit. 24 On economic affairs, Rubin is the power behind the throne. 22 Clinton named a managed-competition critic to a high health post. 23 A STARTLING ASSERTION ON AIDS

Some experts say the American AIDS epidemic can be all but stamped out, even without a wonder drug, by prevention efforts that zero in on 25 to 30 hard-hit neighborhoods across the nation. 1 A PLEA TO WACO SECT'S LEADER
Federal agents pleaded with David Korseh over television to release any of his 100 or so followers who want to leave the Branch Davidian compound. 30 'INDEPENDENCE IS THE GOAL'

More than 5 percent of the residents of Smith County, Kan., are at least 85 years old, the highest proportion of any county in the country, and almost half of them live alone. And that is why Smith County offers a demographic preview of the American future. 20 COST-SAVING OR A TRAGIC WASTE?

Scientists say a high-flying robot airplane developed for the military could revolutionize research into ozone depletion and other atmospheric problems. But they fear that it may be scrapped before it can ever be used. 20 In Baltimore, the debate over Norplant in the schools goes on. 28 The Government will toughen standards on mortgage race bias. 27 Arizona acted to stem gambling on Indian reservations.25 Metro 37-48 FEARING A WAVE OF ANGER

Across the country Arab-Americans exuded anxiety late this week that the arrest of a suspect in the World Trade Center bombing would bring out anti-Arab, anti-Muslim sentiment many feel has been latent since the late 1960's. 1 Suspect in bombing identified as Jordanian of Palestinian origin. 38 In inquiry, bruised egos could have political consequences. 39 Bombing changes feeling of immunity from terrorism. 39 THE BOMBING'S ECONOMIC TOLL
Nine days after after a bombing crippled the World Trade Center, the explosion is also threatening to become one of New York City's biggest financial disruptions. 1 BUDGET CUTS MUZZLE A MONITOR

The commission that investigates political spending chicanery in New Jersey, often held up as a national model of campaign reform, says budget cuts are making it an ineffective public guardian. 37 A TRIUMPHANT, FRIGHTENING TIME

After enduring weeks of vitriol in battles over homosexuals in the military, the St. Patrick's Day parade and school curriculums, gay and lesbian New Yorkers are taking stock -- many hurt and angry, others scared but defiant. 37 Five months after defeat, Liz Holtzman is still repairing damage. 37 Doctor found guilty of illegal abortion plans to appeal. 41 Discord comes to Queens, in the form of nude dance club. 41 Bracing for the message from jurors in Glen Ridge sex case. 42 Despite jury-tampering fears, six convicted in mob case. 42 Vote early and often, they say, and Goodman does. 42 Regents' plan would benefit poor school districts. 48 Obituaries 46
Jerome A. Ambro, ex-New York Congressman.
